item.title: Dreamworld reputation in tatters as inquest wraps up - The Guardian

item.title: Theme park 'spot checks', devices stripped down in proposal: Inquest - Brisbane Times
item.description:
Theme park 'spot checks', devices stripped down in proposal: Inquest  Brisbane Times

A major overhaul of all theme park safety including mandatory major inspections has been proposed following the Dreamworld tragedy.

item.description:
Dreamworld inquest revelations shock family  Courier Mail

THE mother of two victims from the Dreamworld Thunder River Rapids disaster has spoken of her frustration after the conclusion of an inquest into the tragedy.

item.description:
Dreamworld tragedy scares people but not soaring road toll  Courier Mail

HUNDREDS of lives have been lost on Queensland roads this year, with seven of those killed in the Southern Stars catchment area.

Extensions that allowed Dreamworld to operate the Thunder River Rapids ride without a proper safety inspection were "unprecedented", an inquest into four ...

Crucial modifications to Dreamworld's Thunder River Rapids ride were never approved by Workplace Health and Safety officers, an inquest into the death of four ...

item.title: Inquiry into Dreamworld tragedy leaves investigators “stunned” - Brag Magazine
item.description:
Inquiry into Dreamworld tragedy leaves investigators “stunned”  Brag Magazine

The inquiry into the 2016 dreamworld tragedy has left investigators "stunned" due to the lack of saftey protocol followed by staff.

A Workplace Health and Safety inspector identified a "litany of safety concerns" about the Thunder River Rapids ride that claimed four lives in the Dreamworld...

item.title: Dreamworld’s tiger sisters celebrate third birthday on Tiger Island - Herald Sun
item.description:
Dreamworld’s tiger sisters celebrate third birthday on Tiger Island  Herald Sun

DREAMWORLD has celebrated a very special birthday as tigers Adira and Akasha turned three last week.

item.description:
Dreamworld ride faulty on day of deaths  Forbes Advocate

A senior Dreamworld staffer has admitted it should have been "obvious" to staff manning the Thunder River Rapids ride on the day four people were killed at th...

Dreamworld's Thunder River Rapids ride was unsafe when four tourists were killed and the Gold Coast theme park had shown little learning from past ...

item.description:
Dreamworld wanted to be 'sophisticated'  Fraser Coast Chronicle

A ride safety engineer said Dreamworld was working to get on the level of places like MovieWorld and Wet 'n' Wild before the 2016 tragedy.

item.description:
Dreamworld rides not checked by expert  Newcastle Herald

A safety expert considered one of the toughest ride inspectors in Australia has told the inquest into four Dreamworld deaths he was never asked to audit the a...

item.description:
$15mil expansion announced for Dreamworld’s WhiteWater World water park  Gold Coast Bulletin

DREAMWORLDs water park is set to get a makeover as work begins on a multimillion-dollar expansion.

item.title: 'I am dreadfully sorry': Ex-Dreamworld safety boss apologises to families - Brisbane Times
item.description:
'I am dreadfully sorry': Ex-Dreamworld safety boss apologises to families  Brisbane Times

After giving evidence at an inquest into the 2016 deaths of four tourists at the park, former safety manager Angus Hutchings addressed the victims' families.

item.description:
Dreamworld ride 'should not have opened'  9news.com.au

The ill-fated Thunder River Rapids ride would never have opened if Dreamworld had recognised the red flags leading up to the malfunction that killed four ...

item.title: Dreamworld safety boss says database not popular with staff: Inquest - Brisbane Times
item.description:
Dreamworld safety boss says database not popular with staff: Inquest  Brisbane Times

The former head of safety at Dreamworld parent company Ardent Leisure says the safety database at the adventure park was difficult to use and not popular with ...

item.title: Ardent hopes for smoother ride - The Australian
item.description:
Ardent hopes for smoother ride  The Australian

The Ardent Leisure Group has pledged to implement all recommendations stemming from the coronial ­inquest into the 2016 Dreamworld tragedy in which four visitors lost their lives, and has laid out plans to expand its Main Event Entertainment business in the US from 2020. Speaking at the group’s annual meeting in Sydney yesterday, chairman Gary Weiss said the past year had been “challenging” but the group was committed to ­restoring value for its shareholders from both its local theme parks business and its growing US unit. Ardent has a new board and management, has sold off its d’Albora Mar...

item.title: Dreamworld ride closed for good - The Australian
item.description:
Dreamworld ride closed for good  The Australian

Ardent Leisure Chief Executive Officer Deborah Thomas announced the permanent closure of the ride this morning.

She said the closure was “only respectful and appropriate course of action”.

“Out of respect for the memories of Cindy Low, Roozbeh Araghi, Kate Goodchild and Luke Dorsett, and their deeply affected families, the ride will be permanently decommissioned,” Ms Thomas said.

Ms Thomas said the independent review of the park’s rides by engineering firm Pitt & Sherry was ongoing.

“Dreamworld is also well progressed on an internal review of every ride in t...

item.title: Ariadne’s Ardent tilt not takeover - The Australian
item.description:
Ariadne’s Ardent tilt not takeover  The Australian

It is now understood that the acquisition of the shares by the $147 million property rival, which counts corporate raider Gary Weiss as a director, is not a precursor to a takeover. Rather, it is a move to influence the company, which has plans to expand in the US at a time some consider its ability to pay for such moves to be questionable. Ariadne’s raid on Ardent was revealed online yesterday by The Australian, and shares rallied as a consequence, closing 18c, or 11.04 per cent, higher at $1.81. It is understood Queensland billionaire Kevin Seymour, who is an Ariadne director, may also be...

item.title: Gold Coast mayor backs fun park - The Australian
item.description:
Gold Coast mayor backs fun park  The Australian

Song Cheng, which operates 30 theme parks in China, has plans for an indoor skifield, ­animal exhibits, an adventure park and 3500-seat performance theatre at Nerang even though Dreamworld’s attendances fell 36 per cent in May ­compared with the previous period. Rival Village Roadshow, said in April it was “significantly impacted by the tragedy that ­occurred at Dreamworld in ­October 2016”. Nevertheless, Mr Tate said he had encouraged Song Cheng to expand its global entertainment and theme park attractions to ­incorporate Australia, specifically the Gold Coast even though it ­already sport...

item.title: Year In Review: Best Mumbrella opinion pieces of 2016 - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Year In Review: Best Mumbrella opinion pieces of 2016  mUmBRELLA*

How our fake business won a Customer Service award Former agency executive Marc Cowper, now boss of start-up Recomazing, embarked on an experiment to see how easy it is to buy endorsements from influencers for a fake business. To his dismay, he won an award, which he argues highlights the potential for manipulation and dishonesty by social media influencers. How to Ritson: A beginner’s guide to denial, dismissal & downplay Professor Mark Ritson was one of the most talked-about figures in Australian adland after a series of explosive presentations calling out the ‘tsunami of bullshit’ he cla...

item.title: Balnaves’ Dreamworld nightmare - The Australian
item.description:
Balnaves’ Dreamworld nightmare  The Australian

It was Ardent chief executive Deborah Thomas calling from Sydney. The Sydney-based leisure and entertainment group, which owned Dreamworld theme park on the Gold Coast, AMF bowling centres and a string of Main Event entertainment centres in the US, had been in the process of selling its marina business. “Deborah said she had some bad news,” he told The Weekend Australian. “I thought she must have been joking as I was expecting the news on the sale. “But she said ‘No. I really have some bad news for you’.” Thomas told him about the tragedy at Dreamworld that had happened only hours before. F...

item.title: Ardent’s US head exits - The Australian
item.description:
Ardent’s US head exits  The Australian

Ardent (AAD) has not disclosed a reason for the resignation, but says Charlie Keegan would consult for the bowling and games centres business over the next 12 months to facilitate an orderly transition. A global search firm has been started to find a suitable successor to lead the Main Event business through its next phase of development, the company said in a statement. It comes after analysts in June questioned the company’s rollout of its Main Event centres, warning some parts of the business were struggling. Citi analyst Sam Teeger warned that Main Event “continues to underperform” in l...

item.title: Seymour, Weiss lash Ardent - The Australian
item.description:
Seymour, Weiss lash Ardent  The Australian

The pair, who directly and via listed investment company Ariadne hold nearly 8 per cent of Ardent, are preparing a proposal aimed at restoring value to the company, which they say has had $900 million wiped off its value. The Ariadne camp has been trading barbs with Ardent and last week the temperature was dramatically lifted as the combatants each laid out stinging criticisms. Ariadne yesterday mocked Ardent’s attempts to portray its performance as “strong” and “materially outperforming”, querying why the company had announced four strategic reviews in a little over a year and commissioned...

item.title: Raiders air plan to ‘fix’ Ardent - The Australian
item.description:
Raiders air plan to ‘fix’ Ardent  The Australian

An analysis of Ardent (AAD), the owner of Dreamworld, by the pair, who are pushing for four board seats, sets out a new course for the company over the next three years. Ariadne chief Dr Gary Weiss and Mr Seymour said it was critical that Ardent’s board be strengthened as the current board had presided over a substantial loss of value during the past few years. “On any objective basis, Ardent’s operational and financial results, coupled with its governance issues over the last few years, have been poor,” Dr Weiss and Mr Seymour said. “We believe that all four nominees have the proven skills...

item.title: Ariadne unveils Ardent stake - The Australian
item.description:
Ariadne unveils Ardent stake  The Australian

In a filing with the ASX this morning, Ariadne reported it had 5.73 per cent of Ardent Leisure stock in a 50/50 arrangement with Seymour’s Kayaal Pty Ltd. Ardent’s shares have been under pressure since the accident on the Thunder River Rapids ride at Dreamworld last October which left four people dead and closed the park for many weeks over the summer. “We believe the intrinsic value of Ardent to be higher than its market capitalisation,” Weiss told the Australian today after the announcement. “We believe we have bought value.” Ardent’s shares had been trading as high as $2.85 before the tr...

item.title: Wait on for Weiss’s Ardent moves - The Australian
item.description:
Wait on for Weiss’s Ardent moves  The Australian

It may be that new advisers and consultants will be brought in to cast a fresh eye over the business as the new directors help Ardent to examine the best way to move forward. Recently appointed chief executive Simon Kelly approached Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse to work with Ardent Leisure. Mr Kelly was previously the chief financial officer at Nine Entertainment and is thought to have close relationships with advisers at the two banks from his time working at the free-to-air broadcaster. It will be interesting to see if any other changes come about on the back of the director appointment...

item.title: Ardent to reopen Dreamworld - The Australian
item.description:
Ardent to reopen Dreamworld  The Australian

The company (AAD) will reopen parts of the Gold Coast theme park from Saturday, December 10, but some areas and major rides will remain shut while further safety investigations are carried out into last month’s tragedy.

In a statement to the Australian Securities Exchange today, Ardent Leisure said the Dreamworld and WhiteWater World closure during November meant the park received zero revenue for the month. In the same time last year, the park accrued $7.6 million in earnings.

item.title: Theme park ‘to reopen next week’ - The Australian
item.description:
Theme park ‘to reopen next week’  The Australian

The Australian understands Workplace Health and Safety Queensland inspectors gave the parks the all-clear yesterday after issuing seven improvement notices and three prohibition notices last week.

Bothparks have been closed since four holiday-makers died on the Thunder River Rapids Ride at Dreamworld last month.

It is understood Ardent Leisure’s board will meet this morning to decide when the parks will reopen, likely in stages. Parts of the parks could open their doors as early as Monday.

Though WHSQ has finished its work at Dreamworld, individual ride...

item.title: Ardent battle favours Weiss - The Australian
item.description:
Ardent battle favours Weiss  The Australian

Weiss and other directors of Ariadne, including billionaire property developer Kevin Seymour and chairman David Baffsky, called the EGM to shake up the board and put up two new directors. Early indications suggest the Ariadne directors have enough support for their proposal to be voted in. Ariadne is proposing for Weiss and US-based Brad Richmond to join the board as they push for more value to be created for shareholders within the company. Should the Ariadne directors fail to succeed in their proposal, staging a takeover is not on the agenda, but the theory is that they may increase their...

item.title: Village sells Singapore stake - The Australian
item.description:
Village sells Singapore stake  The Australian

The move will help the company, which last month proposed to sell the freehold of its iconic parks on the northern Gold Coast with price expectations of up to $100m, to cut debt after an initial deal to sell the interest to Singapore filmmaker mm2 Asia did not go ahead. Village will reap a net profit of about $150m from the sale to Orange Sky, which already holds the other 50 per cent interest in the movie exhibition business, Golden Village. The deal is expected to be completed before the end of the year and will give the company greater flexibility as it also pursues the property sale. In...

item.title: Village hit as thrillseekers depart - The Australian
item.description:
Village hit as thrillseekers depart  The Australian

Local visitors have been staying away from the company’s Gold Coast theme parks, which include Warner Bros Movie World, Sea World and Wet ‘n’ Wild, after the tragic deaths late last year at Dreamworld, owned by rival Ardent Leisure. Attendance at the parks was further dampened when Cyclone Debbie hit in late March. “I was up there a couple of weeks ago and it was the quietest I’ve ever seen it,” Baillieu Holst analyst Nick Caley told The Australian. “It’s such an unprecedented event — I don’t think anybody knew how long it was going to take to get confidence back in the rides.” Village Road...

item.title: Girl, 11, dies after falling from Drayton Manor theme park ride - The Guardian
item.description:
Girl, 11, dies after falling from Drayton Manor theme park ride  The Guardian

An 11-year-old girl has died after falling into the water on a ride at a theme park near Birmingham. The girl, from Leicester, was on a school trip to Drayton Manor in Tamworth, near Birmingham, when she fell from the Splash Canyon water ride on Tuesday afternoon. She was believed to have been on the ride with a teacher and other pupils. One report suggested she had stood up during the ride, in which up to six people sit on a large round inflatable raft, and hit her head as she fell into the choppy water. George Bryan, a director of Drayton Manor, was visibly shaken as he read a statement. ...

item.title: Dreamworld to announce reopening - The Australian
item.description:
Dreamworld to announce reopening  The Australian

The Australian understands Workplace Health and Safety Queensland inspectors gave the park the all-clear today, after issuing seven improvement notices and three prohibition notices last week.

Both parks have been closed since the accident that claimed the lives of Luke Dorsett, Kate Goodchild, Roozi Araghi and Cindy Low on October 25.

The accident happened on the Thunder River Rapids ride at Dreamworld.

It is understood Ardent Leisure’s board will meet tomorrow morning to decide when the parks will reopen, likely in stages. Parts of the parks could open its doors as...

item.title: Doubting Thomases hit target - The Australian
item.description:
Doubting Thomases hit target  The Australian

The former editor of The Australian Women’s Weekly leaves Ardent after just over two years at the helm in which she rarely left the spotlight. Ms Thomas became a lightning rod for criticism over the company’s handling of an accident in which four people were killed at the iconic Queensland theme park last October. She was deeply affected by the incident but even before that time Ms Thomas had battled very public controversies, stemming back to her surprise appointment in March 2015, which led to a sharemarket mauling. Critics also narrowed in on the drawn-out sale of Ardent’s marinas, surpr...

item.title: 'Industrial manslaughter' to be made offence in wake of Dreamworld accident - ABC News
item.description:
'Industrial manslaughter' to be made offence in wake of Dreamworld accident  ABC News

Industrial manslaughter is set to become a criminal offence in Queensland following an independent review prompted by the death of four people on a Dreamworld water ride last year. Two men and two women were killed on the Thunder River Rapids ride at Dreamworld on the Gold Coast when the ride malfunctioned, throwing two people out and trapping two inside. Industrial Relations Minister Grace Grace has moved to introduce legislation in State Parliament to make industrial manslaughter an offence. "Industrial manslaughter ... is about not only the individual but the corporation, and that's now ...

item.title: Theme park accidents: How fun days out turned to tragedy - The Telegraph
item.description:
Theme park accidents: How fun days out turned to tragedy  The Telegraph

The death of a young girl at Drayton Manor Theme Park is just one such tragedy which has occurred because of a rollercoaster. In recent years, there have been many casualties as a result of theme park rollercoasters. Drayton Manor An 11-year-old girl died after falling off a rollercoaster at Drayton Manor. The girl, who was on a school trip, fell from the Splash Canyon water ride at Tamworth-based Drayton Manor Theme Park on Tuesday afternoon. Splash Canyon Ride at Drayton Manor Theme ParkCredit: SWNS.com The child, from the Leicester area, was pulled from the water by park staff. Paramed...

item.title: Big wet forces Qld closures, cancellations - The Advertiser
item.description:
Big wet forces Qld closures, cancellations  The Advertiser

* 763 state schools, 1286 Catholic and private schools and 546 child care centres are now closed. * Beaches along 600km of coastline between Agnes Water and the NSW border have been closed. * The Australian Surf Lifesaving Championships on the Gold Coast has been suspended until further notice. * Gold Coast theme parks Dreamworld, Movie World, Wet'N'Wild and Sea World all closed for the day. * Griffith University campuses and Queensland University of Technology campuses to close from noon. University of Queensland campuses across the southeast have been closed for the day. Bond University a...

item.title: Ride makes for high drama - The Australian
item.description:
Ride makes for high drama  The Australian

The Queensland Fire and Rescue Service used a cherry-picker to pluck passengers — aged ­between 10 and 50 years old — off the Arkham Asylum Coaster after it stalled because of a suspected fault with a lift chain. It was the second evacuation from a Movie World rollercoaster over the summer, and followed the deaths of four people on a ride at the nearby Dreamworld theme park in October. Yesterday’s incident sparked calls for a specialist unit to be set up by Queensland’s Workplace Health and Safety office to regul­ate rides and theme parks. Movie World confirmed there were 20 passengers on t...

item.title: Thomas out as Ardent CEO - The Australian
item.description:
Thomas out as Ardent CEO  The Australian

The sudden departure concludes her reign of just over two years, which was marred by the tragic accident in which four visitors at Dreamworld were killed and a loss of investor faith in the company’s direction. Ardent has dumped Ms Thomas’s proposed shift into a highly paid role as chief customer officer but granted her a lucrative consultancy agreement as it seeks to put the fallout from last year’s tragedy behind it. However, these agreements may act as a lightning rod for the growing dissent on the company’s register, with shareholders yesterday saying it needed to take a new direction a...

item.title: Ardent’s revenue dives - The Australian
item.description:
Ardent’s revenue dives  The Australian

Ardent said theme parks revenue fell 63 per cent to $3.66 million between December 10 and December 31, traditionally one of the busiest times as it coincides with the start of school ­holidays. “WhiteWater World opened in its entirety, however the progressive reopening of Dreamworld’s thrill rides throughout the remainder of the month negatively impacted attendance and revenues,” the company said. Across Dreamworld and WhiteWater World 29 slides and rides were open, including five of the “big nine thrill rides”, driving more consistent traffic following an independent safety review. The com...

item.title: Dreamworld hunts for new head of public relations - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Dreamworld hunts for new head of public relations  mUmBRELLA*

Gold Coast theme park, Dreamworld, is on the hunt for a new head of PR and internal communications four months after the Thunder River Rapids ride tragedy which left four people dead. The job, posted on the seek.com.au earlier this month, is asking for “an experienced head of public relations and internal communications”. The advertisement comes after the Dreamworld tragedy which left four people dead in an accident on the Thunder River Rapids ride in October last year. It is widely considered that Dreamworld parent-company Ardent Leisure mishandled communications regarding the event in the...

item.title: Tragedy still weighs on Ardent - The Australian
item.description:
Tragedy still weighs on Ardent  The Australian

The Gold Coast tragedy has weighed on the entire theme park sector across the country, but none more so than Ardent as it tries to rebuild its damaged reputation. In a January market update today, Ardent (AAD) said it booked unaudited revenues of $6.97 million in the theme parks unit for the month, down 50.4 per cent on the corresponding period last year. The extent of the fall was a modest improvement on December, when it reported a 63 per cent plunge in revenues. Much of the improvement was pinned on the further reopening of its “Big 9 thrill rides”, with eight now back in operation after...

item.title: Is a name change the best way out of a crisis? - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Is a name change the best way out of a crisis?  mUmBRELLA*

When a brand finds itself in the midst of a crisis, there are numerous ways to get past it. One of the more drastic is a name change. Changing identity is one thing, but when you change a brand name you’re basically saying the business is becoming something different. It is the most extreme thing you can do to signal a major shift in who you are and what you do. As long as you actually deliver something different, a name change is an effective way of moving beyond a crisis. However, if you are just trying to look different and not fundamentally changing what you offer or how you offer it, t...

item.title: Twenty people trapped on Australian roller coaster ride - The Telegraph
item.description:
Twenty people trapped on Australian roller coaster ride  The Telegraph

Twenty people were trapped for almost two hours at the top of a roller coaster ride at a theme park on Australia's Gold Coast on Wednesday, said emergency services, only a few months after an accident on a neighbouring theme park ride killed four people. Those trapped on the Arkham Asylum Coaster ride were seated in chairs suspended from the ride. Most were easily rescued, but four could only be reached by emergency personnel using a ladder platform, according to a spokeswoman for Queensland Fire and Emergency Services. No one was injured. The latest incident at the Warner Bros. Movie World...

item.title: Lessons every company needs to learn from the mishandling of the Dreamworld tragedy - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Lessons every company needs to learn from the mishandling of the Dreamworld tragedy  mUmBRELLA*

Over the Easter break this year we took a family holiday to the Gold Coast visiting a number of the theme parks with a couple of very excited young children. Like thousands of families we had a lot of fun. Whilst we didn’t visit Dreamworld, the saddening events of this past week felt all too real and scary, and my thoughts and prayers are with the families and friends of this terrible accident. Having been involved with many clients that have had the tough task of dealing with fatalities at their place of work, I can tell you from bitter experience that crisis and issues management is highl...

item.title: Mantra’s growth defies barriers - The Australian
item.description:
Mantra’s growth defies barriers  The Australian

Theme park operator Village Roadshow yesterday reported 100,000 fewer visits to its Sea World, Warner Bros Movie World and Wet‘n’Wild parks on the Gold Coast, a drop of 8.4 per cent, or 100,000 visitors for the half-year, blaming the decrease on the tragedy at Dreamworld last year. Mantra chief executive Bob East has consistently said the Dreamworld tragedy, where four guests were killed, would not affect Gold Coast hotel occupancies. Twenty-three of Mantra’s 127 hotels in Australia, New Zealand, Indonesia and Hawaii are on the Gold Coast and are operated as Mantra, Peppers and Breakfree br...

item.title: Seymour busy in ‘retirement’ - The Australian
item.description:
Seymour busy in ‘retirement’  The Australian

Seymour Group was looking “all over the city” for property investments, the Brisbane-based developer told The Australian. “It’s where the opportunities present themselves. It’s about looking for value creation opportunities,” he said. The company is purchasing a 7600sq m site in near-city Stones Corner for $27.5 million that it expects to hold for the next development cycle. Mr Seymour said the property, currently serviced offices and a car park at 433 Logan Road, could support a substantial commercial or residential project. “We will wait until the next residential cycle or for a big offic...

item.title: Dreamworld considers hotel expansion - ABC News
item.description:
Dreamworld considers hotel expansion  ABC News

The owner of Gold Coast theme park Dreamworld is considering building a hotel and entertainment precinct at the troubled tourist attraction. Ardent Leisure has seen significant drops in visitor numbers and revenue since four people were killed on a ride at the park in October. In a notice to the Australian Stock Exchange on Wednesday morning, the company announced it was considering the feasibility of rezoning parts of the site. Chief executive Deborah Thomas said the park sat on 60 hectares of land on the northern Gold Coast, but only about half of that space was being used. "We haven't lo...

item.title: Dreamworld safety audit reveals room for improvement - ABC News
item.description:
Dreamworld safety audit reveals room for improvement  ABC News

Eight improvement notices have been issued to Dreamworld by Workplace Health and Safety officers, however the Gold Coast theme park says none relate to the safety of visitors despite the recent deadly ride malfunction. The safety audit follows the accident last month on the Thunder River Rapids ride in which four people died. Two improvement notices were also issued relating to Dreamworld's adjoining facility, WhiteWater World. CEO Craig Davidson said the breaches involved procedural matters, paperwork improvements and the safety of staff and maintenance workers. He said the notices would b...

item.title: Ardent eyes Dreamworld sale - The Australian
item.description:
Ardent eyes Dreamworld sale  The Australian

It comes after the company was believed to have set its sights on rival Village Roadshow as a takeover target. This was before a fatal tragedy at Dreamworld last year that caused its share price to fall and visitor numbers to the Gold Coast theme park to plummet. Songcheng, which owns land on the Gold Coast, may be the party eyeing Dreamworld, given that it currently has plans a rival nearby theme park. Discussions have also previously been held with China’s Wanda, which owns entertainment assets globally about buying Dreamworld, but the talks later went cold. Plans are currently thought to...

item.title: Safety watchdog smacks down Dreamworld - The Australian
item.description:
Safety watchdog smacks down Dreamworld  The Australian

In an extraordinary move, Workplace Health and Safety Queensland has demanded the troubled Gold Coast theme park hand over all documents relating to the ride, now called the Hot Wheels SideWinder.

Dreamworld’s safety, staffing and maintenance practices are already under scrutiny following the deaths of four holidaymakers last week on the Thunder River Rapids ride.

The Australian revealed on Monday that ...

item.title: 'Out of touch' Ardent Leisure board set for a shake down - ABC News
item.description:
'Out of touch' Ardent Leisure board set for a shake down  ABC News

A shake down at embattled Ardent Leisure is growing likely, as major shareholders take action to move on a board they believe is "in complete disarray". The ABC understands major shareholders and well-known businessmen Gary Weiss and Kevin Seymour of Ariadne Australia filed paperwork with the ASX to call an extraordinary general meeting and are now demanding four seats on the board. "We see this requisition as the beginning of a process of board renewal with further changes to board composition in due course," a joint statement issued to The Business program said. Ariadne is not seeking to ...

item.title: Ardent shows signs of recovery - The Australian
item.description:
Ardent shows signs of recovery  The Australian

For the month, the theme parks unit — dominated by Dreamworld but also including WhiteWater World — booked revenues of $4.4 million, a level 35 per cent below last year’s reading. “This represents an improving trend against December 2016 and January 2017, which respectively recorded reductions in revenues of 63 per cent and 50.4 per cent on the prior corresponding periods,” the company said. Ardent (AAD) has provided monthly updates on Dreamworld since reopening the theme park in December, with a dramatic impact on foot traffic noted since a tragic ride malfunction in October claimed the li...

item.title: Movie World’s bizarre Twitter post - The Advertiser
item.description:
Movie World’s bizarre Twitter post  The Advertiser

The tweet, sent at 1pm - which has now been deleted - showed a picture of one of the Gold Coast theme park’s rollercoasters with the message: “Tag someone that you think should add these to their New Year’s Resolutions! #repost #movieworldaus” The message led to several negative comments from other social media users, suggesting the theme park rethink its use of autotweets. All passengers aboard the Arkham Asylum rollercoaster have been evacuated. But the last to be freed were trapped there for almost two hours. The ride malfunctioned about 11.45am and the last passengers were freed at 1.30...

item.title: Ariadne, Seymour seek EGM - The Australian
item.description:
Ariadne, Seymour seek EGM  The Australian

The board of Dreamworld owner Ardent Leisure faces being overthrown after the listed Ariadne and property tycoon Kevin Seymour yesterday issued a notice of intention to call an extraordinary general meeting to install four ­directors on the troubled company’s board. The move comes after months of behind-the-scenes scrapping and could be the first step in a clean-out of the board and turnaround of the ailing company. Mr Seymour and legendary corporate raider and Ariadne executive director Gary Weiss have taken the dramatic step after having trouble winning traction with the existing board, l...

item.title: Movie World, Wet 'n' Wild theme parks affected by Dreamworld tragedy - ABC News
item.description:
Movie World, Wet 'n' Wild theme parks affected by Dreamworld tragedy  ABC News

Village Roadshow has reported attendance by Queenslanders at its theme parks has dropped by more than 12 per cent compared to the prior year since the Dreamworld tragedy, where four people were killed. Queenslanders make up the majority of attendance - around 60 per cent - and the declines have continued into January 2017, Village Roadshow said. "Notwithstanding a minimal impact on ticket sales revenue, the decline in attendance has resulted in deterioration in food and beverage, retail and other in-park revenue," the company said in a statement to the ASX, noting it will "take time for the...

item.title: Ardent reopens Dreamworld - The Australian
item.description:
Ardent reopens Dreamworld  The Australian

Ardent CEO Deborah Thomas flew into the Gold Coast on Tuesday and the company made the announcement to the Australian Stock Exchange on Wednesday morning.

The Australian understands Workplace Health and Safety Queensland inspectors gave the park the all-clear yesterday, after issuing seven improvement notices and three prohibition notices last week.

Both Dreamworld and WhiteWater World have been closed since four holiday-makers died on the Thunder River Rapids ride at Dreamworld last month.

I...

item.title: In the dark on Dreamworld tragedy - The Australian
item.description:
In the dark on Dreamworld tragedy  The Australian

In an interview with The Australian, Mr Araghi said he was mystified that the official police and Workplace Health and ­Safety Queensland investigations into the October 25 deaths of his son Roozi Araghi, Roozi’s partner Luke Dorsett, Luke’s sister Kate Goodchild, and fellow holiday-maker Cindy Low, had not yet been finished. “They haven’t told me what they believe went wrong,” he said. “We’re very much in the dark. “They have been very friendly, they are doing their jobs. I am not dogmatic, I am pragmatic; I know these things take time. Nothing will bring him back.” Mr Araghi said a repres...

item.title: Hotel plan for Dreamworld - The Australian
item.description:
Hotel plan for Dreamworld  The Australian

Dreamworld owner Ardent Leisure signalled yesterday that it was undertaking a review of a previous master plan for the site. Incoming Ardent Leisure chief executive Simon Kelly said Dream­­world’s carpark was an extremely valuable asset. Mr Kelly said it would take a few years for the theme park to recover from December’s tra­gedy when four patrons were killed. “There is a gradual recovery process,” said Mr Kelly, a British-trained accountant who takes over in July. Ardent said it had engaged, and would keep engaging with, third-party developers to talk about potential development ­opportun...

item.title: Margin Call: Thomas exits Ardent - The Australian
item.description:
Margin Call: Thomas exits Ardent  The Australian

Just over two months ago, Ardent Leisure chairman George Venardos announced that Thomas would step down as the group’s chief executive to be replaced by former Nine executive Simon Kelly. The plan, which chairman Venardos revealed in late April, was for Thomas to move from the CEO role to a newly created role as chief customer officer on July 1. As of this evening, that’s no longer the case. Kelly is now Ardent’s CEO. Meanwhile, Thomas is now an outgoing Ardent executive. The chief customer officer role has been scuttled entirely. The former Australian Women’s Weekly editor will also step d...

item.title: New Ardent CEO in for wild ride - The Australian
item.description:
New Ardent CEO in for wild ride  The Australian

In his first interview since his appointment to the troubled entertainment group, Kelly left the door open for a sale or re­development of its troubled flagship, the Dreamworld theme park on the Gold Coast, adding that everything is for sale at the right price. The former Nine Entertainment chief financial officer said he had been headhunted by Korn Ferry for the Ardent role, and was not averse to overseeing a major shake-up of the company’s 38 Main Event businesses — predominantly based in Texas — to get the company back on track. “There are no sacred cows as far as I am concerned,” Kelly ...
